Through the cracks, the player char­acters get a view of the courtyard with the bonfire and see light shining from the two @UUID[.UwoyYWS5AJfct2xZ]{sheds} and @UUID[.7bQyw8ejUyXe98yO]{the keep}. Getting in through the cracks is easy.

  • Guards: Two adventurers are patrolling the top of the wall. They have orders to attack any creature approaching from the outside, and if someone calls out to them, they immediately sound the alarm and await reinforcements. They are only looking outward, so player characters in the courtyard will not be detected as long as they do not make any noise.

  • Climbing: Climbing the wall requires an ACROBAT­ICS roll. Once at the top, it takes another SNEAKING roll to avoid being spotted by the guards.

Attack!

If the player characters want to attack the castle directly, they have a tough battle ahead of them. Two adventurers are patrolling the top of the wall. In the event of an attack, they immediately raise the alarm and are joined by the other adventurers in the next round, and the two dragon knights in the round after that.

The Adventurers

@DisplayNpcDescription[Actor.VFc683LFBEw977im]{Adventurer 1}

@DisplayNpcCard[Actor.VFc683LFBEw977im named]{Adventurer 1}

@DisplayNpcCard[Actor.eOj1C73C6cC0LKjI named]{Adventurer 2}

@DisplayNpcCard[Actor.ewkQQn05PdqtG99v named]{Adventurer 3}

@DisplayNpcCard[Actor.U1IfMmBg7Us7xChX named]{Adventurer 4}

Gatehouse.name: Gatehouse
Gatehouse.text:
The fortress’s five meter high and equally wide double gate of bronze must once have been an impressive sight. Now its surface is as green as the moss that has taken hold along the edges. The outline of a coat of arms – a tree with golden apples – is barely visible. The gate is slightly ajar.

  • Gate: The patinated double gate is ajar, simply because it can no longer be closed. Opening it enough to slip through requires a roll against STR, but this triggers a jar­ring squeak that is noticed by anyone currently outside.

  • Coat of Arms: A MYTHS & LEGENDS roll reveals that the coat of arms on the gate belongs to House Stoneoak, which was powerful in the days of the dragon empire.

The Bonfire.name: The Bonfire
The Bonfire.text:
A bed of embers smokes and smolders in the courtyard. The fire must have been huge, a real bonfire.

  • The Bed of Embers measures three meters in diame­ter and is still hot. Anyone rummaging around in the smoldering ashes must make a BUSHCRAFT roll or take [[/damage D3]] from fire.

  • The Skull: A person who digs through the charcoal finds a human skull.An examination of the skull combined with a successful HEALING roll reveals an injury to the bone – a gash running from the forehead down under the left eye.

  • Random Event: Roll [[/roll D6]] on the @UUID[.nzYj9FS223Oyp5y4#random-events]{Random Events} table for each full stretch the player characters spend here.

The Stone Tree.name: The Stone Tree
The Stone Tree.text:
A half-dead tree behind a meter-high stone wall. It does not look like much – a sprawling, bone-dry crown covered in wrinkled bark, bare but for a handful of small, yellow-red fruits. The surrounding wall is overgrown with thorns so dense that the circle of marble at its top is barely visible.

  • The Tree: Anyone who examines the tree up close and succeeds with a BUSHCRAFT roll can see that the tree is withered, but small pale green buds on some of the lower branches show that it is still alive.

  • The Fruits: [[/roll D4]] scattered fruits hang from the branches. They look like small apples, golden in color and deli­cious. One golden apple is enough food for an entire day but counts as a tiny item in terms of encumbrance.

  • The Marble Circle: Carved into the marble surface at the top of the wall are ancient letters which can be read with LANGUAGES: “The golden tree will be forever in the care and possession of House Stoneoak; such is the agreement with the tree’s keeper and soul, Rotlaug, bound to this place in perpetuity.”

  • Random Event: Roll [[/roll D6]] on the @UUID[.nzYj9FS223Oyp5y4#random-events]{Random Events} table for each full stretch the player characters spend here.

Storage Shed.name: Storage Shed
Storage Shed.text:
Darkness and silence are all that can be sensed from the dilapidated shed. The doorless entrance gapes like a monster’s maw, waiting for delicious visitors.

  • Random Event: Roll [[/roll D6+1]] on the @UUID[.nzYj9FS223Oyp5y4#random-events]{Random Events} table for each full stretch the player characters spend in here.

Iliel's cell.name: Iliel's cell
Iliel's cell.text:
A lantern lights up the interior of the small shed. Light seeps out through cracks in the brickwork and where the centuries-old roof tiles have fallen in. As you approach the moss-covered facade, you hear tense, hissing voices – no words can be made out, at least not until you are just outside.

  • Eavesdropping: Getting close enough to eavesdrop without being detected requires a SNEAKING roll. If it succeeds, two female voices are heard – one irritated and threatening, the other defiant. A few words can be made out:

    • Isadelia: “Why refuse? If [mumble] just translate [mumble] on the cellar door, you are free to get your [mumble] out of here!”

    • Iliel: “No, let me go [mumble] If you [mumble] nicely, I might [mumble] you.But [mumble] coercion and threats, never!”

  • Isadelia: Shortly after the dialogue above, Isadelia turns around and slams open the door. If the player characters are in her line of sight, she spots them immediately, but if they stick to the shadows, they remain undetected – she locks the door behind her and strides purposefully towards @UUID[.7bQyw8ejUyXe98yO]{the keep} without looking back.

  • The Symbol: Isadelia has the symbol of Eledain fully visible on her cloak and cloak buckle. The player char­acters can identify it with a MYTHS & LEGENDS roll.

  • The Door: The door to the shed is old and leaky, but the heavy lock works and picking it requires a SLEIGHT OF HAND roll. It is possible to break the door (10 HP, Armor Rating 6), but not without alerting the enemy.

  • The Roof: It is also possible to enter from the roof, thanks to the many missing roof tiles. It takes an ACROBATICS roll to get up and in without accident; on failure the climber suffers a four-meter fall. If Isadelia is still in the shed, it also takes a successful SNEAKING roll to avoid detection.

  • Iliel: If the player characters enter, a proud and impos­ing elven woman rises to her feet. Her ankles are shack­led, and her hands tied behind her back. She offers to tell them everything she knows in exchange for her freedom.

  • Random Event: Roll [[/roll D6+1]] on the @UUID[.nzYj9FS223Oyp5y4#random-events]{Random Events} table for each full stretch the player characters spend in here.

@DisplayNpc[Actor.9w0mMA17luo7GtEi named]{Iliel}

Blutuld's cell.name: Blutuld's cell
Blutuld's cell.text:
The door to the larger shed is wide open and a faint light spills out onto the grass. Otherwise, it looks just like the building next to it, with its mossy stone facade and broken roof.

  • Knapsack: Blutuld’s knapsack is still here, next to the shackles that previously held him. It contains a sleeping fur, a field kitchen, and a shovel, as well as a nine-hole ocarina shaped like a grinning demonic rooster.

  • Secret Compartment: Anyone who searches the knapsack and succeeds with a SPOT HIDDEN roll finds a secret compartment in its leather hem. Hidden inside is a small silver coin with the symbol of Sathmog on one side.

  • Random Event: Roll [[/roll D6+1]] on the @UUID[.nzYj9FS223Oyp5y4#random-events]{Random Events} table for each full stretch the player characters spend in here.

The Keep.name: The Keep
The Keep.text:
How high it once was is impossible to say, but now the ground floor is all that remains of the keep. Light seeps out through tall, narrow window openings partly covered by creeping vines, and the patinated bronze door is closed. The noise of pickaxes hitting stone echoes from inside, sometimes accompanied by the impatient shouts of a gruff male voice.

The Dragon Knights

@DisplayNpcDescription[Actor.WUpuxirRYYN2oD2H]{Isadelia}

@DisplayNpcCard[Actor.WUpuxirRYYN2oD2H named]{Isadelia}

@DisplayNpcCard[Actor.Pskib7z3tjDAub73 named]{Niklion}

  • The Door: The bronze door is barred from the inside. It is very difficult to break down (80 HP, armor rating 18) and any attempt to do so is heard by every­one nearby.

  • Backdoor: The smaller door leading the other way, to a small courtyard with a dry well, does not close all the way. However, it takes a successful SNEAKING roll for it to be opened without a revealing squeak.

  • Through the Roof: In the southeast corner of what used to be floor on the second level, the stairway open­ing still remains. Since the weathered facade is easy to climb, the ACROBATICS roll is made with a boon.

  • The Dragon Knights: Unless someone has sounded the alarm, both dragon knights can usually be found in the great hall of the keep. They are not very alert but will attack any intruder on sight. However, both @UUID[Actor.WUpuxirRYYN2oD2H]{Isadelia} and @UUID[Actor.Pskib7z3tjDAub73]{Niklion} do leave the hall from time to time, which could be a good moment for the player characters to strike – together they pose a serious challenge in combat.

  • The Adventurers: The adventurer or adventurers who are not guarding the wall are digging their way through the floor on the orders of the dragon knights. There is a sledgehammer and a pickaxe in the room. Player characters who find the door’s riddle as unsolvable as the dragon knights can keep digging. See “The Price of Digging” below.

  • Cellar Door: The massive ironclad cellar door is patinated, but not as much as the door to the keep. It has no normal lock and cannot be picked or opened with UNLOCK. Breaking it down is almost impossible (100 HP, armor rating 25). The best way to open it is to decipher the inscription and place the crystals in the correct order.

  • The Inscription: On the upper part of the cellar door there is an inscription in an ancient language, and below it a tree with a leafy crown. A closer look reveals five horizontal indentations at chest height, each one round and about the size of a silver coin. A bright yellow crys­tal lens has already been placed in the leftmost indenta­tion but is easily removed. It takes a LANGUAGES roll to decipher the text – see the sidebar below.

The Inscription

The drop is east of the heart, but not in the center
The heart is not by the leaf, but just east of the sun
The sun is neither in the far west nor the far east
The moon is next to the drop alone
The leaf is west of the heart

The Correct Order: Leaf/Green, Sun/Yellow, Heart/Red, Drop/Blue, Moon/Off-White

The Price of Digging

Digging oneself through the floor and into the cellar takes one shift and a successful CRAFTING roll. A new attempt is allowed each shift, but the noise might attract dangerous creatures from the Iron Forest. Roll on the table below once per shift of digging.

@DisplayTable[RollTable.QweV54YXXgLNszxQ]{The Price of Digging}

Cellar.name: Cellar
Cellar.text:
Once the crystal coins are placed in the right order, the whole door flares up with an inner light that shines through the lenses with blinding intensity. The door slides open by itself. The musty smell of the darkness beyond the threshold mixes with an acrid, pungent stench. A croaking, chuckling voice says: “Rotlaug is free! Make way, time to make things grow.”

  • Rotlaug: The nature spirit Rotlaug is as crooked as a dwarf birch, with skin as rough and pale as the bark of a birch tree. His face is dominated by a wide, toothless mouth. His nose is like a small bud and his eyes like tiny peppercorns. As for his goals in life, he has only two: to be free and take revenge for all his years in captivity (see below).

  • The Cellar: A crypt with a stone floor (about 6×6 meters) and a low ceiling. Almost everything that was down here has crumbled into dirt.

  • Treasures: Most of House Stoneoak’s fortune was eaten up by the conflicts that marked the final years of the empire, but in a cracked urn the player characters can find valuables equivalent to [[/treasure 4]]. If a piece of the dragon statuette was placed in this adven­ture, it is here as well.

Rotlaug’s Revenge: If Rotlaug is freed, he walks out into the courtyard, surrounded by the swarming hornets who have awaited their master’s return, and unleashes all his life-giving power. He becomes part of the apple tree, which quickly grows many times larger and attacks Fort Malus – its branches and roots crashing into the ruins as they cling to the walls and ceilings. Meanwhile, grass shoots up between growing cracks in floors and foundations. Wild­flowers sprout, bud, and bloom all over the courtyard.

If one or both of the dragon knights are still around when this happens, they try to stop Rotlaug, but are soon crushed by vengeful roots. The adventurers flee for their lives. If any player character tries to stop or harm Rotlaug, they too are attacked by ferocious branches and roots, which counts as a monster attack that inflicts [[/damage 3D8 blud­geoning]]. Rotlaug cannot be defeated in combat by any means available to the player characters.

A few minutes later, Rotlaug’s revenge is complete – Fort Malus has been turned into an overgrown ruin, hard to dis­tinguish from the forest that surrounds it. If there are trea­sures left in the ruin’s cellars, the player characters can still access them. At the center of the ruin sits the now enormous apple tree, with [[/roll 4D6]] golden apples ready to be plucked. An additional [[/roll 4D6]] fruits can be harvested every autumn.

Tower of Sighs.name: Tower of Sighs
Tower of Sighs.text:
This must once have been a mighty fortress, four stories high and built of red stone. The roof is flat and surrounded by battlements, but the tower is badly damaged. One broken wall is wide open and blackened with soot. There are stones scattered across the ground around it, as if a huge fireball once blasted through the wall. Up close one can hear distinct sighs that make one’s blood run cold.

  • Ground Level: The ground floor of the tower is cov­ered in broken masonry. In one corner Glam-Glam has set up a sleeping area with branches and animal skins. There are clean-picked bones from cows and pigs, but also some assorted valuables (draw [[/treasure 2]]).

  • The Giant: This is where @UUID[Actor.YXnSL5FjDEUd2Bsy]{Glam-Glam} is usually found, sleeping. The player characters can get past him with a successful SNEAKING roll, otherwise he wakes up.

  • Staircase: In the middle of the ground floor is the entrance to the basement. A spiral staircase once ran through the tower’s center – the way up has collapsed, and the way down is blocked by a massive boulder. That is where the sighs are coming from.

  • The Way to the Cellar: The boulder must be removed in order to enter the cellar. The easiest way is to get Glam-Glam to do it. Otherwise, it must be chipped away, which takes at least a shift of hard work and of course wakes up the giant. Pickaxes, chisels, and sledgehammers can be found on the second floor.

  • Rope Ladder: There is a rope ladder hanging at the entrance of the tower. It leads up to the collapsed upper floors and onto the roof.

  • Upper Floors: The rope ladder goes up through a hole in the floor to the second and third levels. There is nothing of interest there except some loot the bandits have tucked away (the equivalent of [[/treasure 2]]) in a locked chest. It must be picked or smashed open (armor rating 5, 20 HP). The latter wakes the giant. Leaning against a wall are various stone-working tools – pickaxes, digging bars, and sledgehammers.

  • Roof: On the roof are two simple benches. The bandits sometimes keep a lookout here.

@DisplayMonsterDescription[Actor.YXnSL5FjDEUd2Bsy named]{Glam-Glam the Giant}

The Situation.name: The Situation
The Situation.text:
In the days of the old draconic empire, the Tower of Sighs was located on an island in a shallow lake. In a cave on the island was a spring whose waters made it impossible to tell lies. The knights of Eledain built a watchtower on top of the spring and set up a temple in the cave. At the altar in front of the spring, the knights swore oaths to the emperor and the empire.

After the collapse of the empire, the temple fell into disrepair and came to be used as a neutral meeting place for various orc clans who had heard tales of the Truth Temple in the tower’s cellar. When one clan decided to lure their enemies into a trap, a violent battle broke out and a fire spell destroyed large parts of the tower. Several orc leaders were trapped in the cave and died of starvation. Since then, the place has been haunted by the restless spirits of the dead.

Long afterwards, the broken tower was found by the wandering giant Glam-Glam. He set up a lair on the ruined ground floor and took to hunting and pillaging in the area. He was recently joined by a gang of bandits who had heard rumors of a treasure in the tower’s cellar.

The bandits and their leader Ursic offered Glam-Glam a share of their loot if he would remove the stones block­ing the way to the cellar. The giant accepted but is more cunning than the bandits think. He has been dragging out the clearing work and getting the bandits to share their stolen goods. That way, he does not have to plunder the land himself and incur the wrath of the peasants.

Ursic has started thinking about killing the giant and clearing the last blocks of stone from the entrance them­selves. But her bandits need help to defeat Glam-Glam.

Rumors in Outskirt speak of a treasure in a ruin in the Haunted Marshes, and there are @UUID[JournalEntry.EobTKNtJU1ScMlAa]{whispers} of brigands plaguing the swamp. The Tower of Sighs is a possible location for one of the four pieces of @UUID[JournalEntry.PAMgObFsFBOGo4qb.JournalEntryPage.R2aO3v0kURd5DGk2#the-dragon-statuette]{the dragon statuette} – if so, it can be found in @UUID[.PSd85uNkHNEE8wID]{the forgotten temple}.

ENCOUNTER IN THE SWAMP

The player characters can encounter the bandits even before they reach the Tower of Sighs. You can also replace this encounter with a regular @UUID[JournalEntry.XZIHvVIMqHiHVhjN.JournalEntryPage.xgOv4JJnxCyBlRnD#in-the-haunted-marshes]{random encounter} in the Haunted Marshes.

The Haunted Marshes is a vast wetland full of buzzing insects, croaking toads, and squawking marsh birds. Low trees with spidery aerial roots form a forest crisscrossed by channels and muddy paths. Suddenly, two voices are heard from amongst the thickets.

“We won’t make it to the tower before dark and you’re walking so slowly,” says one. The other replies, “Ursic will kill us if we don’t get back tonight. Can’t you carry the keg now? It’s so darn heavy.”

The voices belong to two young men in light leather armor. The player characters can roll SNEAKING and follow the bandits to the Tower of Sighs. If they fail, or deliberately make themselves known, the two bandits draw their swords and position themselves back-to-back.

The bandits defend themselves if attacked but would rather negotiate. Their names are @UUID[Actor.HgWKXcZCOylAjRt6]{Rilke} and @UUID[Actor.ZQ8UEuyftP27LYcP]{Feder}. Feder asks where the player characters are headed and wonders if they would be interested in a profitable proposition. He says they belong to a small “adventuring party” that has gotten a whiff of treasure in a tower.

The problem is that the treasure is guarded by a giant, a treacherous figure who at first offered to help dig up the treasure but is now only delaying the work. The expedition’s leader, Ursic One-Ear, has been talking about hiring help to slay the giant. Are the player characters interested? Feder and Rilke can introduce them to Ursic, who will surely give them a share of the treasure in exchange for their help.

If the player characters accept, Feder and Rilke can lead them straight to the island with the Tower of Sighs. Other­wise, they will have to find the way on their own.

The Island and the Bandit Camp.name: The Island and the Bandit Camp
The Island and the Bandit Camp.text:
A great rock surrounded by low trees rises from the swamp. At the top of the cliff is a large tower of red stone. The narrow staircase that once led up to the entrance has been razed and there are gaping holes in the side of the building. The wind carries sighs and bloodcurdling wails from the tower.

  • Tower of Sighs: The tower is the highest point in the swamp and can be seen from afar. By now the wails of the undead have made the bandits very nervous.

  • Bandit Camp: Ursic and the @UUID[Actor.boKYWZzu90kbDfkG]{other bandits} (as many as the characters but at least three, in addition to @UUID[Actor.8ZbshVMTlg8NwCxP]{Ursic}, @UUID[Actor.ZQ8UEuyftP27LYcP]{Feder} and @UUID[Actor.HgWKXcZCOylAjRt6]{Rilke}) are in the camp with two tents and a small fire, between the tower and the grove where the path reaches the island.

  • The Giant in the Tower: @UUID[Actor.YXnSL5FjDEUd2Bsy]{Glam-Glam} is sleeping on the ground floor of the tower.

Discussions: If the player characters are accompanied by Feder and Rilke, or if they come alone but in peace, Ursic invites them to sit down. She offers them a third of the giant’s treasure if they help drive him away. With a suc­cessful BARTERING roll, she can agree to share it equally. However, she will let the player characters take all the risks and betray them once the treasure is retrieved.

@DisplayNpc[Actor.8ZbshVMTlg8NwCxP named]{Ursic One-Ear}

@DisplayNpc[Actor.boKYWZzu90kbDfkG named]{Ursic's Bandits}

The Forgotten Temple.name: The Forgotten Temple
The Forgotten Temple.text:
When the last stone is rolled aside, the sighs stop. Every­thing turns still and silent. An owl hoots far away in the swamp. A translucent figure steps into the light.

  • Staircase Down: Under the last boulder on the ground floor is a spiral staircase, carved into the rock.

  • Temple Hall: After fifty steps the staircase opens into a square room. The bare rock walls were once covered with tapestries, but now only threads and dust remain.

  • Banner: Against a wall stands an object that has inexplicably withstood the ravages of time – a war banner depicting a grinning wolf, mounted on a pole of patinated bronze. All orcs within sight get a boon on all attacks if it is carried by an orc, and a bane on all attacks if it is carried by a non-orc. The banner is worth a lot to the orc chieftain Maladûk.

  • Altar: Against the far wall is an altar, carved from the same red stone as the tower itself. If a piece of the dragon statuette is found here, it is standing on the altar, otherwise it is empty.

  • Spring: Behind the altar a spring wells up into a semi-circular basin. Anyone who drinks from the spring and then swears an oath can never break that oath. The water has no effect if it is moved from the spring.

  • Skeletal Remains: Bones and skulls are strewn all over the floor, under tattered clothes, with orcish gold jewelry glittering among them. These are the remains of orcs who starved to death down here. Draw [[/treasure 2]] to determine what is found here.

  • Wraiths: As the player characters enter the room, about twenty translucent figures rise from the skeletal remains. Silently they make their way up the stairs and disappear.

  • Acha Bonebreaker: A single wraith lingers in the room. It is an orc woman in an ankle-length robe, with heavy jewelry around her neck and a tiara on her head. She speaks to the player characters in an archaic dialect (roll LANGUAGES to understand), “I am Acha Bonebreaker of Clan Takrûk.In gratitude for freeing us, I give you three gifts (two if the statuette piece is not here).” She points at the banner. “This is the Banner of Takrûk, which can aid an orc commander in righteous battle.” She points at the spring. “This is the Fountain of Truth.Drink from it and swear an oath that cannot be broken.” If the statuette is here, she then points at the altar. “This is a relic from the days of the Dragon Empire. Farewell!”

  • The Dead Depart: Acha follows the other spirits upstairs. As they leave the tower, the spirits dissolve and scatter like stardust across the island. All is quiet.

Aftermath.name: Aftermath
Aftermath.text: If the player characters made a deal with Ursic to fight the giant, they will be betrayed. Ursic was expecting to find a great treasure of gold under the tower and thinks the char­acters are lying. The situation may deteriorate into vio­lence. However, if the player characters have an arrange­ment with Glam-Glam, he can come to their rescue.

Oracle Cave.name: Oracle Cave
Oracle Cave.text: A child has been abducted from Outskirt and the trail leads to the Oracle Cave, a winding cave system beneath the Iron Forest. Few ever venture there due to rumors that an ancient horror dwells in its depths – some age-old creature from before humanity’s arrival in the Misty Vale that is said to possess hidden knowledge. People call the place the Oracle Cave.

The Situation.name: The Situation
The Situation.text:
The player characters can hear about the disappearance of young Roric and the Oracle Cave through @UUID[JournalEntry.EobTKNtJU1ScMlAa]{rumors} in Outskirt. The place is a possible location for one of the four pieces of @UUID[JournalEntry.PAMgObFsFBOGo4qb.JournalEntryPage.R2aO3v0kURd5DGk2#the-dragon-statuette]{the dragon statuette}, which in that case is found in @UUID[.cj5i1Nc15CQvPqJG]{the she-spider’s lair}.

Roric is a little boy of six who has been abducted from Outskirt. He was playing outside the family farm when he was taken by brigands, who brought him to the Iron Forest. There they were ambushed by giant spiders who captured the bandits and the boy and brought them to the old she-spider Saak’shal – the one that people in the Misty Vale call the Oracle.

When the player characters arrive at the Oracle Cave, they should not have figured out that there are giant spi­ders involved. Ideally, this should only become clear after they find spiderwebs down in the caves. This is a deep cave system, and the player characters will need a light source in each room unless they want to feel their way through total darkness.

Leaving the Cave?

If the player characters leave the cave to take a long rest, roll D6 per shift on @Table[RollTable.BU27Xp8XL0b1g4Yh]{Leaving the Adventure Site}.

Random Events

For each full stretch the player characters spend in certain rooms, perhaps searching for something or taking a stretch rest, you can roll on the table below or select a suitable event. The room descriptions indicate where random events can occur.

@DisplayTable[RollTable.lZPW4LtJHPtvMrr8]{Random Events}

Entrance.name: Entrance
Entrance.text:
A dark hole, wide enough for several people to walk next to each other, gaping straight down into the earth. The cold of the underground flows from the opening.

  • Primitive Altar: Small wooden bowls filled with fruits and pieces of dried meat have been lined up on a rock just inside the entrance – small offerings from locals to appease the oracle. Occasionally, the she-spider Saak’shal emerges from her lair and answers questions in return.

  • Blood Trails: If the player characters examine the floor or roll SPOT HIDDEN in the cave, they find several trails of blood in the tunnel – from both animals and humanoids.

  • NORTH: A natural opening in the rock wall leads to the @UUID[.DcW5Ylk5rp2LvYpN]{cave tunnel}.

Cave Tunnel.name: Cave Tunnel
Cave Tunnel.text:
The tunnel runs deep into the rock and slopes steeply down­wards. It is cold, damp, and pitch black. The cave walls are dripping with moisture and there is a musty smell of algae.

  • Random Event: Roll [[/roll D10]] on the @UUID[.v6DKm42bqVragpSz#random-events]{Random Events} table for each full stretch the player characters spend in a tunnel.

  • NORTH, SOUTH: Tight openings to @UUID[.nahMbBerZvxAkZoI]{narrow passageway}.

The Fork.name: The Fork
The Fork.text:
The tunnel opens into a larger space with two paths ahead. There is a dark figure lying on the floor.

  • Dead Orc: The figure is the corpse of a massacred orc who was devoured by the offspring of Saak’shal. Their arms and legs are torn off, and in some places the bones have been picked clean.

  • The Mark of Maladûk: If the player characters search the corpse or roll SPOT HIDDEN, they find valuables equivalent to [[/treasure]] and scraps of armor branded with @UUID[JournalEntry.PAMgObFsFBOGo4qb.JournalEntryPage.R2aO3v0kURd5DGk2#the-orcs]{the mark of Maladûk}.

  • Random Event: Roll [[/roll D10]] on the @UUID[.v6DKm42bqVragpSz#random-events]{Random Events} table for each full stretch the player characters spend here.

  • NORTH, EAST: Tunnels to the @UUID[.J8wiePOE7efec631]{underground river}. A rushing sound is heard.

  • WEST: Opening to the @UUID[.DcW5Ylk5rp2LvYpN]{cave tunnel}.

Underground River.name: Underground River
Underground River.text:
The tunnel is crossed by raging black water that disappears into the darkness to the east. The passage continues on the other side of the river, which is about four meters wide.

  • Treacherous Crossing: The river’s current is strong and its water freezing (BUSHCRAFT roll to resist cold). Swimming across requires a SWIMMING roll with a bane. Those who fail are swept away to the @UUID[.Uh1PR9WKr7MrssiL]{under­ground lake} and must make another SWIMMING roll to avoid drowning. Player characters can try to @UUID[JournalEntry.SbbSMsuvWeo3HaID.JournalEntryPage.KrSXg7HKmfo7xRcI#movement]{jump} across the river, use magic, or cross by other means. Make sure to reward resourceful players.

Underground Lake.name: Underground Lake
Underground Lake.text:
An underground lake spreads out like a cold, black mirror. The darkness makes it hard to see where the cave ends and the lake begins.

  • The Eel Beast: Something lurks beneath the surface. @UUID[Actor.u2Dx9taJztD3Ax8f]{A hungry sea serpent} dwells in the lake and attacks anyone who gets in the water. A player character watching the lake for a while can roll AWARENESS to notice some­thing moving in the water.

  • Slippery Rocks: The edges of the lake are dark and slippery. A player character wishing to pass the lake without getting wet must roll ACROBATICS (not an action) to avoid falling in. The same applies to char­acters trying to get out of the water. One attempt is allowed per round.

@DisplayMonsterDescriptionCard[Actor.u2Dx9taJztD3Ax8f named]{The Eel Beast}

Narrow Passageway.name: Narrow Passageway
Narrow Passageway.text:
This passageway is so narrow that you must crawl and climb to get through. The tunnel seems to go on forever into the darkness.

  • Narrow Passage: Passing through a narrow tunnel requires an ACROBATICS roll. A player character who leaves all their items (not counting any weapons in their hands) gains a boon on the roll. On failure, the character gets stuck and suffers a condition of their choice. Another ACROBATICS roll can be made each stretch. Others can help.

  • Random Event: Roll [[/roll D10]] on the @UUID[.v6DKm42bqVragpSz#random-events]{Random Events} table for each full stretch the player characters spend in a narrow tunnel.

The Relic Cave.name: The Relic Cave
The Relic Cave.text:
Along the walls of the cave lie old swords and armor cov­ered in dust and dirt. Yellowed bones and blankly glaring skulls can be seen here and there.

  • The Weapons: Most of the gear is broken beyond repair, but the player characters can find a broadsword, a flail, a chainmail, and an open helmet that are still in usable condition. A successful MYTHS & LEGENDS roll reveals that these are ancient relics, likely from the draconic empire of Eledain.

  • Treasures: If the player characters search the cave and succeed with a SPOT HIDDEN roll, they find valuables equivalent to [[/treasure]] among the dirt on the floor.

  • Random Event: Roll [[/roll D10]] on the @UUID[.v6DKm42bqVragpSz#random-events]{Random Events} table for each full stretch the player characters spend here.

  • EAST: @UUID[.nahMbBerZvxAkZoI]{Narrow passageway} leading directly to @UUID[.MRjMyJ16iBH2SFvE]{the keep}.

  • SOUTH: Tunnel to the @UUID[.Uh1PR9WKr7MrssiL]{underground lake}.

  • WEST: Tunnel to @UUID[.fQRq6XAAh95HAEqY]{the spiderlings’ lair}.

The Spiderlings' Lair.name: The Spiderlings' Lair
The Spiderlings' Lair.text:
The tunnel opens into a cramped cave chamber whose walls, floor, and ceiling are covered in thick white webs. Suddenly a swarm of spiders bursts out of every nook and cranny of the room – the smallest are the size of a fist, the largest as big as well-fed cats.

  • The Spawn of Saak’shal: In this lair dwell the young­est offspring of the old she-spider Saak’shal – a swarm of @UUID[Actor.ElUvCNcayx1VQRbv]{spiderlings}. They attack instantly.

  • Relics: If the player characters search the cave and succeed with a SPOT HIDDEN roll, they find valuables equivalent to [[/treasure]] among the dirt on the floor.

  • Random Event: Roll [[/roll D10]] on the @UUID[.v6DKm42bqVragpSz#random-events]{Random Events} table for each full stretch the player characters spend here.

  • NORTH: Tunnel to @UUID[.ARSWRjGOopPNsKGA]{the offspring’s lair}.

  • EAST: Tunnel to the @UUID[.l7HsIQm06sjIeGjV]{relic cave}.

  • SOUTH: Tunnel to the @UUID[.J8wiePOE7efec631]{underground river}. A rush­ing sound is heard.

  • WEST: Opening to a @UUID[.nahMbBerZvxAkZoI]{narrow passageway}.

@DisplayMonsterDescriptionCard[Actor.ElUvCNcayx1VQRbv named]{Spiderlings}

The Offspring's Lair.name: The Offspring's Lair
The Offspring's Lair.text:
Hanging from the damp ceiling of the cave are half a dozen white cocoons of cobwebs, each the size of a full-grown human.

  • The She-Spider’s Offspring: In this lair dwell the older offspring of the ancient female – @UUID[Actor.yqvaDFsdDOKuEtmL]{giant spiders}. They are half as many as the player characters, rounded up. Lurking in dark crevices, they wait for the player characters to start exploring the room before they attack. The attack counts as an @UUID[JournalEntry.SbbSMsuvWeo3HaID.JournalEntryPage.KrSXg7HKmfo7xRcI#sneak-attack]{ambush }and the player characters get a bane on their AWARENESS rolls.

  • Cocoons: The she-spider’s offspring have gathered dead humans and orcs in thick web cocoons to be eaten later. The bodies have no visible injuries as they were killed by spider venom, which a successful HEALING roll can reveal. Player characters who exam­ine the corpses can find valuables equivalent to [[/treasure]].

  • The Surviving Brigand: Suddenly, the body inside one of the cocoons wakes up and cries out in terror. All player characters must make a WIL roll to resist fear. But the “corpse” is alive – it is one of the brigands who abducted Roric. He begs the player characters to cut him loose. “Please, before they come back! I’ll do anything! Don’t leave me here!” If the bandit is freed, he will break any promises and escape at the first opportu­nity. If pressed, he admits to having participated in the abduction of Roric, but claims it was not his idea.

  • SOUTH: Tunnel to @UUID[.fQRq6XAAh95HAEqY]{the spiderlings’ lair}.

  • WEST: Tunnel to @UUID[.cj5i1Nc15CQvPqJG]{the she-spider’s lair}.

The She-Spider's Lair.name: The She-Spider's Lair
The She-Spider's Lair.text:
The dim light barely illuminates what appears to be a vast cave chamber. The far wall is covered in cobwebs from which a small cocoon is dangling. You see the outline of something very large moving in the shadows, and then a faint voice speaks inside your heads, as if whispering in both ears at once.

“Little creatures… Why have you invaded our home?”

Out of the abyss climbs a hideously large spider, thick as two fat horses and with just as many legs. The spider braces itself against the walls as she looms over you.

  • Saak’shal: The @UUID[Actor.D7u2e7uwVdSG7XUs]{ancient she-spider} has inhabited the caves beneath the Iron Forest since long before the first humans arrived in the Misty Vale. Realizing that the player characters must be capable to have made it this far, she wants to know who they are and what they are doing here. Saak’shal can read their minds and snarls at them if they lie. She does not really want to fight but defends herself ferociously if attacked.

  • Roric: The terrified child is hanging in the cocoon of cobweb behind the she-spider, saved for later as a particularly delicious treat. It is possible to SNEAK over there if Saak’shal is distracted, but she reacts with violent fury if she notices it.

  • Negotiation: If the player characters explain that they are looking for young Roric and/or a piece of Eledain’s dragon statuette, Saak’shal offers them a deal – they will get what they want if they first kill a group of orcs who have settled in another part of the cave (@UUID[.MRjMyJ16iBH2SFvE]{the keep}). She will keep her promise if they carry out the mission.

  • The Statuette Piece: If you want to place a piece of @UUID[JournalEntry.PAMgObFsFBOGo4qb.JournalEntryPage.R2aO3v0kURd5DGk2#the-dragon-statuette]{Emperor Eledain’s statuette} here, Saak’shal reveals that she has it. Even if there is no statuette piece, the old she-spider can tell the player characters where to find one, in exchange for them carrying out her mission.

  • Legends: Saak’shal knows all there is to know about the Misty Vale and can pass on @UUID[JournalEntry.PAMgObFsFBOGo4qb.JournalEntryPage.UDUP0IaN4LR1kXfi#the-legend-of-um-durman]{the legend of Um-Durman} as well as the @UUID[JournalEntry.EobTKNtJU1ScMlAa]{rumors} about the other adventure sites.

  • The She-Spider’s Treasure: At the bottom of the cave are countless treasures that Saak’shal has amassed over the years. The entire treasure is equivalent to [[/treasure 6]] but cannot be accessed without killing the ancient spider.

  • EAST: Tunnel to the @UUID[.nJ75dSfRWfI06fE9]{woven bridge}.

  • SOUTH: Tunnel to @UUID[.ARSWRjGOopPNsKGA]{the offspring’s lair}.

@DisplayMonsterDescriptionCard[Actor.D7u2e7uwVdSG7XUs named]{The She-Spider Saak´Shal}

The Woven Bridge.name: The Woven Bridge
The Woven Bridge.text:
The tunnel opens into a seemingly bottomless shaft. A dark abyss gapes before you. Thick cobwebs form a bridge to the other side where a passage continues into the mountain.

  • The Cobweb Bridge: The bridge of cobwebs sways under the weight of the player character. Describe how the thick, sticky web is all that separates them from the chasm below. The web is strong and will not give way but climbing over the bridge is difficult and requires a successful ACROBATICS roll. On failure the victim slides toward the abyss but can save themselves with EVADE. Each of the other player characters on the bridge also gets one attempt to catch the falling person with ACROBATICS. If all attempts fail, the victim falls 12 meters into an underground lake and takes [[/damage 3D6]] from falling.

  • EAST: Passageway to @UUID[.MRjMyJ16iBH2SFvE]{the keep}.

  • WEST: Passageway to @UUID[.cj5i1Nc15CQvPqJG]{the she-spider’s lair}.

The Keep.name: The Keep
The Keep.text:
The passage turns into a steep stairway in a narrow, carved tunnel that leads sharply upward. After a few minutes of arduous ascent, the tunnel opens to reveal a small keep with an extensive view of the Iron Forest. Orcish grunts can be heard from the lookout on the other side of a wall.

  • The Keep: The outpost dates back to the old draconic empire, which a successful MYTHS & LEGENDS roll can reveal.

  • Agra and the Orcs: The orc warrior @UUID[Actor.qclcQ28CZgitApD0]{Agra} and her @UUID[Actor.ka2mD6FLxclW4V2W]{patrol of orcs} (as many as the player characters) have been in the Iron Forest for a few days, trying to find pieces of Eledain’s statuette for their chieftain Maladûk. They came to the keep from the forest and have sent some scouts into the cave, but none have returned. Now they are discussing their next move. Agra reacts violently if she spots the player characters, but she can be reasoned with (PERSUASION or BLUFFING). If the player characters are allied with Maladûk and convince Agra of this, she is willing to cooperate.

  • No Campaign? If you are playing The Oracle Cave separately, with no connection to the The Secret of the Dragon Emperor campaign, Agra is only here to find the cave’s hidden treasures.

  • SOUTH: Stairway down to the Iron Forest.

  • WEST: Tunnel to @UUID[.nJ75dSfRWfI06fE9]{the woven bridge}.

@DisplayNpc[Actor.qclcQ28CZgitApD0 named]{Agra}

@DisplayNpc[Actor.ka2mD6FLxclW4V2W named]{Orc Warriors}

Riddermound.name: Caverna del Cavaliere
Riddermound.text: “In quest’area della Foresta di Ferro si trova un luogo empio, con enormi rocce che si innalzano verso il cielo. È chiamato Cripta del Cavaliere, dal guerriero oscuro che fu incatenato dagli dèi quando il mondo era giovane. Si dice che fu seppellito vivo nel tumulo, insieme alla sua famiglia, ai suoi servitori e a tutte le sue ricchezze.”

Bothild's Lode.name: Vena di Bothild
Bothild's Lode.text: “I nani dei Monti Kummer sono gente rispettabile e onesta. Erano peggio nei tempi passati, durante il regno di Bothild la Vile e Avida, quando scavarono troppo in profondità nelle loro misere miniere e liberarono nel mondo orrori indicibili. Ma d’altra parte, quali tesori hanno trovato! Hanno estratto cumuli d’oro, argento, smeraldi scintillanti e cristalli grandi quanto la testa di un goblin. A quanto pare, è tutto ancora là sotto, nella Vena di Bothild, nel lontano sud-ovest.”

Tower of Sighs.name: Torre dei Sospiri
Tower of Sighs.text: “C’è una disgustosa palude a circa un giorno di marcia a est da qui. È infestata da sanguisughe e insetti succhiasangue, ed è un rifugio per i banditi. Ma ci sono immense ricchezze là nella melma, sepolte tra le rovine di un’antica torre di guardia. La gente di qui la chiama la Torre dei Sospiri.”

Temple of the Purple Flame.name: Tempio della Fiamma Purpurea
Temple of the Purple Flame.text: “Il Boscomagno è una foresta malata e tutti sanno da dove proviene questa malattia: dal Tempio della Fiamma Purpurea, il ricordo cadente di un’era malvagia, dove conoscenze proibite e resti demoniaci riposano tra tesori incalcolabili sotto rocce coperte di vegetazione.”

Oracle Cave.name: Caverna dell’Oracolo
Oracle Cave.text: “Hai sentito del piccolo Roric? Il bambino è stato rapito dalla sua fattoria, fuori Orlo. Le tracce conducono nella Foresta di Ferro. Dicono che sia stato portato nella Caverna dell’Oracolo. L’Oracolo è antico e sa tutto ciò che c’è da sapere sulla Valle Nebbiosa. Si dice anche che lei sieda su un’immensa ricchezza. Ma ogni tanto richiede un sacrificio umano. Penso che non vedremo Roric mai più.”

Troll’s Spire.name: Guglia del Troll
Troll’s Spire.text: “Con la luna piena, puoi vedere una torre scintillante, simile a una guglia argentata, nella parte occidentale della valle. È senza dubbio una torre magica, perché nessuno ha ancora scoperto come raggiungerla. Alcuni dicono che sia la dimora di un’antichissima alchimista che molto tempo fa provocò l’ira dell’imperatore drago. Si nascose da Eledain nella propria torre, dove creò un elisir che le conferì la vita eterna.”

Dead Eyes Cave.name: Caverna degli Occhi Morti
Dead Eyes Cave.text: “Una bestia mostruosa è strisciata giù dalle montagne e ha attaccato la fattoria di Hildi la Cieca, a sud-est di Orlo. Si sussurra di una caverna piena di occhi strappati, ma anche di grandi tesori e potenti armi di sfortunati avventurieri che hanno incontrato la loro fine nella Caverna degli Occhi Morti.”

Road’s End Inn.name: La Locanda Fine Strada
Road’s End Inn.text: ““C’è qualcosa di strano nella Locanda Fine Strada, al confine con le Paludi Infestate. Diversi ospiti sono scomparsi senza lasciar traccia, tra cui un bambino piccolo e, più recentemente, la pastorella Antelia. La sua famiglia è tremendamente preoccupata.”

The Village of the Day Before.name: Il Villaggio del Giorno Prima
The Village of the Day Before.text: “Sette secoli or sono, questa valle era la dimora di Kato il Curioso, uno stregone che servì l’imperatore Eledain, per poi tradirlo. La torre di Kato e il vicino villaggio di Crestanera, nel lontano nord-est, furono distrutti dal fuoco di drago non appena il suo tradimento venne scoperto. Ora si dice che Kato infesti le rovine della sua torre, che dovrebbero contenere ogni tipo di tesoro. Nessuno di coloro che hanno tentato di saccheggiare le rovine, però, è mai tornato.”

Fort Malus.name: Forte Malus
Fort Malus.text: “Forte Malus fu costruito dal Casato dei Querciapietra verso la fine del regno dell’imperatore Eledain per proteggere il bene più prezioso della famiglia, il Malus Aureus, un albero che produceva frutti dorati, vere mele d’oro! Le rovine di Forte Malus si innalzano tuttora nel lontano nord-ovest, probabilmente con migliaia di mele d’oro che giacciono tra le radici del vecchio albero.”

The Isle of Mist.name: Isola della Nebbia
The Isle of Mist.text: “L’isola nel Lago Specchiato, all’estremità settentrionale della valle, è un luogo di morte, evitato da tutto ciò che vive e respira. Storie raccontano di un’antica magia e di una cripta colma di oro e splendidi artefatti. Ma l’isola è avvolta in una nebbia demoniaca che risucchia la vita di qualunque cosa si avvicini.”

The Orc Clans.name: Tribù degli Orchi
The Orc Clans.text: “Una vita umana fa, erano gli orchi a gestire la Valle Nebbiosa. Nessuno sa perché se ne sono andati, ma delle voci dicono che una capoguerra di nome Maladûk stia radunando le tribù per reclamare la valle.”

Deepfall Breach.name: Deepfall Breach
Deepfall Breach.text: Location for the solo adventure @UUID[JournalEntry.JIkqLGi5ys4HK4Eu]{Alone in Deepfall Breach}.

Inledning.name: Introduzione
Inledning.text:
Benvenuto in questa raccolta di avventure per Dragonbane! In queste pagine troverai undici avventure complete, che insieme formano l’epica campagna Il Segreto dell’Imperatore Drago; queste, ad eccezione dell’Isola della Nebbia (il finale della campagna), possono essere giocate in qualsiasi ordine. Ognuna può anche essere giocata singolarmente se preferisci. Prima delle avventure, troverai la scena di apertura della campagna, ovvero una descrizione dettagliata del villaggio di Orlo nella Valle Nebbiosa, dove avviene la prima avventura, e un capitolo con gli incontri casuali che possono verificarsi nel corso dei viaggi nella valle. Buon divertimento!

Solo per gli Occhi del GM

Questo libro è soltanto per il Gamemaster. Se intendi goderti queste avventure da giocatore, non leggere oltre, o rischi di rovinare la suspense a te e al resto del gruppo.

LA VALLE NEBBIOSA

Le avventure in questo libro avvengono nella Valle Nebbiosa, un luogo leggendario che per secoli non è stato toccato dagli umani. Secondo i miti, la valle un tempo era il cuore di un potente impero che venerava i draghi, il quale però cadde in rovina abbandonandola all’invasione degli orchi.

La Valle Nebbiosa è circondata da alte montagne, i Monti Kummer a sud e i Picchi Zanna del Drago a nord. Resti di un antico sistema stradale si trovano negli avvallamenti e nei passi tra le cime delle montagne. Scendere nella valle, però, è un’impresa pericolosa che richiede abili esploratori e coraggiosi spadaccini. I pericoli sono molti e la via è infida.

Pettegolezzzi

Ogni sito d’avventura è presentato in un @UUID[JournalEntry.EobTKNtJU1ScMlAa]{pettegolezzo}. Rivelalo ai giocatori quando ne sentono parlare da un PNG.

La valle si estende per circa 150 chilometri in lunghezza e larghezza ed è stata chiamata “Nebbiosa” a causa della foschia impenetrabile che spesso la avvolge. Il territorio consiste principalmente di fitte foreste secolari, ma vicino al Fiume Kummer ci sono due grandi laghi e una vasta area paludosa conosciuta come Paludi Infestate. Attorno a Orlo, che negli ultimi anni è emerso nella regione meridionale della valle, ci sono dolci colline e pianure parzialmente coltivate.

Anche nella valle si trovano porzioni di strade imperiali che molto tempo addietro collegavano le diverse parti della regione, con zone abbandonate alla natura e il selciato che si sgretola e ogni tanto spunta tra il muschio e le erbacce. Anche colonne in pietra spaccate e strane pietre miliari, con appuntite corone cornute in cima, si innalzano dal terreno a intervalli regolari.

History.name: Storia
History.text:
Mille anni or sono, il malvagio demone Sathmog venne nel nostro mondo e il suo profeta fu il sacerdote di nome Azrahel Koth. Il demone sussurrò oscuri segreti al suo orecchio finché la magia di Azrahel Koth divenne talmente potente da permettergli di aprire un portale tra i mondi che il suo oscuro signore usò per ottenere una forma fisica.

Con Azrahel Koth come suo araldo, Sathmog proclamò un regno demoniaco nel mondo degli umani, che durò per due secoli. Fu un tempo di oscurità e malvagità, ma anche di rapida espansione umana, a spese delle stirpi più antiche: nani, elfi, giganti e halfling.

Con il passare del tempo, gli oppositori di Sathmog aumentarono, finché un giorno un giovane eroe di nome Eledain riuscì a evocare i draghi antichi, incaricati di proteggere il mondo dall’influenza demoniaca. A cavallo di un drago e con le stirpi più antiche al suo fianco, Eledain sconfisse il demone. La bestia fu bandita su una collina nelle profondità della foresta, ma come suo atto finale lanciò una maledizione che, disse, avrebbe diffuso una malattia in tutto il mondo, fino a distruggerlo un giorno.

Azrahel Koth fu catturato, ma dato che il suo signore l’aveva reso immortale, i cavalieri di Eledain non poterono ucciderlo in nessun modo. Fu quindi imprigionato in una cripta sotto un’isola in un lago di una valle remota, con guerrieri condannati a rimanere a guardia di essa fino alla fine dei loro giorni.

L’IMPERO DI ELEDAIN

Eledain fondò un nuovo impero, basato sulla venerazione dei draghi e del loro fuoco purificatore. Il suo regno si espanse, furono costruite città, e strade lastricate vennero realizzate attraverso le foreste e le valli. Ben presto i popoli antichi si stancarono dell’avanzata degli umani e molti se ne andarono. I nani si rifugiarono nelle montagne e crearono un nuovo regno sotterraneo.

Al tramonto della sua vita, Eledain iniziò a diffidare e a temere i draghi che l’avevano condotto alla vittoria contro Sathmog. Per mantenere il suo potere al sicuro, l’imperatore drago sacrificò parte della sua anima per forgiare Um-Durman, una spada magica con il potere di annientare draghi e demoni allo stesso modo. Finalmente gli umani sarebbero stati liberi e indipendenti dagli esseri primordiali.

Quando, infine, Eledain morì, la spada fu nascosta in una cripta, dato che i sacerdoti drago la consideravano troppo pericolosa per essere usata, se non per estrema emergenza. Per aprire la cripta era necessaria una chiave speciale: una statuetta divisa in quattro parti, una per ogni direzione governata dall’imperatore drago.

Dopo la sua morte, scoppiò una lotta per il potere tra i suoi figli e l’impero prese una piega tirannica. Tutte le proteste contro i cavalieri drago furono severamente punite e il regno fu tormentato da scontri. Infine, i draghi voltarono le spalle all’impero, che collassò poco dopo. Orchi selvaggi invasero buona parte della regione e molti umani furono costretti all’esilio.

Tutto ciò che rimase del regno di Eledain furono le fievoli parole dei monaci e dei cavalieri che continuarono a venerare la Fiamma Immacolata. Ma la leggenda narra che parte dell’impero dei draghi sia sopravvissuta al di là del mare, nell’estremo oriente.

AZRAHEL KOTH

Passarono secoli e le storie di Sathmog, Eledain e Um-Durman divennero miti e leggende. Ma Sathmog non aveva dimenticato. Intrappolato tra i mondi, sognò la sua vendetta e la sua enorme rabbia lo rese più potente.

Ottocento anni dopo il suo esilio, il demone divenne forte a sufficienza da risvegliare il suo servitore Azrahel Koth dal suo torpore magico. La sua influenza demoniaca trasformò i suoi carcerieri in schiavi non-morti, che si avventurarono nella Valle Nebbiosa per reclutare con la forza anime viventi per le schiere di servitori di Azrahel Koth.

Lo stregone, non potendo ancora lasciare la sua prigione, evocò bestie mostruose per espandere il suo potere nella regione. La sua malvagità colpì la natura stessa e una spessa nebbia ricoprì la valle. Gli orchi nell’area, che temevano queste forze demoniache, decisero di andarsene, permettendo agli umani e alle altre stirpi di ripopolare la regione, ignari dell’origine della nebbia. Molti di questi umani caddero poi sotto l’influenza demoniaca di Sathmog.

L’obiettivo di Azrahel Koth è di ottenere la libertà e di far tornare nuovamente Sathmog nel mondo, sconfiggere una volta per tutte i draghi e ristabilire il regno del suo signore.

Current Situation.name: Situazione Attuale
Current Situation.text:
È passato un decennio da quando nella Valle Nebbiosa, così chiamata per la pesante foschia che la avvolge, hanno iniziato a fare ritorno gli umani, attirati da voci e leggende su ricchezze nascoste e conoscenze perdute dell’antico impero che venerava i draghi.

Ugualmente importante è stato quanto hanno riportato i nani dei Monti Kummer, che per secoli avevano commerciato con gli insediamenti umani: i feroci orchi, che da tempo dominavano la valle, sembravano ritirarsi.

Molti avventurieri hanno assicurato la spada alla cintura e si sono fatti strada verso la misteriosa vallata, ma anche i coloni con picconi e carri trainati da buoi sono stati ugualmente attratti dal luogo leggendario.

IL VILLAGGIO DI ORLO

Il villaggio di Orlo è emerso come risultato dell’afflusso di umani degli ultimi anni. È un semplice insediamento di circa cinquanta case di nuova costruzione, raggruppate attorno alle rovine di un antico tempio.

Ci sono all’incirca 200 abitanti permanenti, molti dei quali umani, e anche molti avventurieri, cacciatori e altri viandanti che usano l’insediamento come base per i loro viaggi nella Valle Nebbiosa.

Gli abitanti di Orlo sono audaci e avventurosi, colmi di spirito pionieristico e determinati a riprendere la valle e tutti i suoi segreti e tesori nascosti. Ma solo in pochi sanno che il villaggio giace sulle rovine di un antico tempio che una volta era il cuore dell’impero draconico, l’ultima dimora della spada Um-Durman.

LA STATUETTA DRACONICA

Molti ignari avventurieri sono caduti vittima del potere di Azrahel Koth e i suoi cultisti sono aumentati rapidamente. Quando ha udito la leggenda di Um-Durman, lo stregone demoniaco ha realizzato che quella spada poteva ucciderlo, ma anche che era la chiave per la sua liberazione e, ancora di più, una potente arma contro i draghi.

Azrahel Koth sa che la spada è sepolta sotto le rovine del tempio nel villaggio di Orlo e che serve una chiave speciale per poter sbloccare l’ingresso, la statuetta di pietra nera vulcanica che raffigura l’imperatore drago Eledain.

Secondo le antiche scritture, la statuetta è stata divisa in quattro pezzi, una per ciascuna direzione governata da Eledain, e deve essere riassemblata per poter aprire l’accesso a Um-Durman.

I Quattro Pezzi della Statuetta

La statuetta dell’imperatore Eledain è alta circa mezzo metro ed è scolpita nella roccia nera vulcanica. Raffigura un imperatore guerriero con un’armatura a piastre completa e un grande elmo decorato da una visiera dalla forma draconica.

In cima all’elmo c’è la stessa corona cornuta che si vede sulle pietre miliari sparse per la Valle Nebbiosa. Eledain impugna uno scettro in una mano, mentre con l’altra stringe una possente spada lunga con la punta piantata nel piedistallo.

La statuetta è divisa in quattro pezzi, che sono mostrati nella grande mappa della Valle Nebbiosa. Ogni pezzo conta come un quarto di oggetto nell’inventario dei personaggi.

  • Il @UUID[Item.P0syImZy02Hcp0gB]{primo pezzo} include il piedistallo, le gambe e la metà inferiore della lama della spada lunga, la cui punta è unita alla base.

  • Il @UUID[Item.i5duTh8mLqtOpcwA]{secondo pezzo} consiste in cosce, vita, parte sinistra del busto e il braccio sinistro, incluso lo scettro.

  • Il @UUID[Item.2buX0G17z61J4l6W]{terzo pezzo} comprende la parte destra del busto, il braccio destro e la metà superiore della spada lunga.

  • Il @UUID[Item.R2tOrqn6j8Gn6Eqe]{quarto e ultimo pezzo} è la testa con l’elmo cornuto.

I quattro pezzi si uniscono alla perfezione. Quando sono posti uno accanto all’altro, sono attratti da una forza invisibile e non possono più essere separati. L’intera statuetta conta come un oggetto normale (peso 1) e irradia calore dall’interno.

Per aprire l’ingresso verso Um-Durman, la statuetta deve essere posizionata in un’apposita nicchia dentro le rovine del vecchio tempio del villaggio, che è descritto nei dettagli nel punto #8 del capitolo sul villaggio di Orlo.

I CULTISTI DEMONIACI

Azrahel Koth ha molti servitori corrotti che cercano i quattro pezzi della statuetta. Uno di loro era Drigel Meteorologo, il cultista morente che i personaggi incontrano nella @UUID[JournalEntry.u2mHxypmg0aZHDB4]{scena di apertura} della campagna. Meteorologo aveva trovato un pezzo della statuetta nei Monti Kummer poco prima dell’inizio dell’avventura e stava tornando a consegnarla al suo signore.

Un’altra cultista è @UUID[Actor.qdhDPr97V8C6RP5F]{Leanara}, gli occhi e le orecchie di Azrahel Koth a Orlo. Può essere fonte di informazioni e di missioni per i personaggi, ma serve anche lo stregone come spia e assassina.

Tutti i cultisti demoniaci della Valle Nebbiosa hanno il simbolo nero di Sathmog marchiato da qualche parte sul corpo, solitamente sull’avambraccio, nascosto dai vestiti. Il marchio è la testa stilizzata di un demone con due corna appuntite.

GLI ORCHI

Azrahel Koth non è l’unico che sta cercando la spada Um-Durman. La presenza dei suoi servitori demoniaci ha fatto preoccupare gli orchi della valle e diverse tribù si sono unite sotto la capoguerra @UUID[Actor.dESAouUNSB7OHgi0]{Maladûk} per scacciare i seguaci di Sathmog.

La capoguerra conosce la leggenda di Um-Durman e sa che Azrahel Koth non potrà mai essere sconfitto se riuscisse a impadronirsi di quell’arma antica. Ha deciso di ritirarsi insieme ai suoi guerrieri scelti in attesa della battaglia finale, ma ha anche mandato pattuglie di orchi e goblin in groppa a lupi alla ricerca dei quattro pezzi della statuetta.

Tutte le creature che servono Maladûk portano sulla spalla destra il marchio di due uncini da carne incrociati.

Luce Solare: A causa della fitta foschia che ricopre la Valle Nebbiosa, gli orchi e i goblin possono muoversi liberamente all’aperto durante il giorno senza subire danni.

I CUSTODI DELLA FIAMMA IMMACOLATA

La terza fazione impegnata nella ricerca della statuetta e di Um-Durman sono i Custodi della Fiamma Immacolata, un ordine religioso di monaci e cavalieri che venerano l’imperatore drago Eledain. Si considerano gli eredi degli antichi cavalieri drago e cercano di ristabilire l’impero di Eledain, basato sul principio del fuoco purificatore.

I Custodi della Fiamma Immacolata aborrono i demoni, specialmente Sathmog, che le loro scritture descrivono come la radice di ogni male. Il loro obiettivo è trovare Um-Durman e tenerla al sicuro consegnandola al capo del loro ordine, fuori dalla Valle Nebbiosa.

Ciò che nemmeno l’ordine sa è che il ritorno di Azrahel Koth ha attirato l’attenzione dei draghi antichi dei Picchi Zanna del Drago…

Course of Events.name: Corso degli Eventi
Course of Events.text:
Il Segreto dell’Imperatore Drago è una serie di avventure ambientate nella Valle Nebbiosa. La campagna ha una scena di apertura già scritta e un’avventura finale nella quale gli avventurieri affronteranno Azrahel Koth e la sua armata di servitori demoniaci nel labirinto sotto l’Isola della Nebbia.

In mezzo, i personaggi possono esplorare la valle e svolgere le avventure nell’ordine che preferiscono. Come GM, sei tu a decidere in quali avventure troveranno i quattro pezzi della statuetta. Questo significa che controlli anche la lunghezza della campagna, senza spingere i giocatori in una direzione specifica.

Le Carte Avventura: I giocatori dovrebbero essere liberi di scegliere quali avventure affrontare, ma puoi influenzare la loro scelta presentandone solo alcune alla volta. Per farlo, utilizza le @UUID[Cards.xkPvASnmdQUFd611]{carte avventura}. Ogni carta contiene un pettegolezzo riguardo a un luogo d’avventura, che può essere riferito da un PNG appropriato. Ti consigliamo di fornire ai giocatori 2–3 @UUID[JournalEntry.EobTKNtJU1ScMlAa]{pettegolezzi} tra cui scegliere e di aggiungerne altri man mano che la campagna procede.

La Scena di Apertura: La storia inizia quando i personaggi incontrano un uomo morente lungo la strada per la Valle Nebbiosa, attraverso il Passo di Drakmar. Prima di esalare il suo ultimo respiro, porge loro un pacchetto insanguinato e fa riferimento a un “segreto dell’imperatore drago”. Subito dopo, i personaggi vengono attaccati da una pattuglia di goblin incaricata di prendere il pacchetto, che contiene un pezzo della statuetta draconica. L’uomo morente ha anche una mappa della Valle Nebbiosa.

Il Villaggio di Orlo: Dopo la scena di apertura, i personaggi arrivano a Orlo. La cultista Leanara cerca di ingannarli mandandoli alla ricerca dei pezzi mancanti della statuetta al posto suo. I personaggi possono anche incontrare Alfilia Fogliombrosa dei Custodi della Fiamma Immacolata, il mistico Dranath e altri che conoscono la leggenda della statuetta dell’imperatore drago e altre storie della valle. Nel corso della campagna, Orlo sarà un luogo importante per i personaggi, un posto dove tornare tra le avventure per riposare, acquistare attrezzatura o cercare informazioni.

La Cripta del Cavaliere

Se non sai con quale avventura cominciare, consigliamo @UUID[JournalEntry.x7niLkijdgURlA2h]{La Cripta del Cavaliere}. È relativamente breve e semplice, una buona introduzione per dei nuovi giocatori. Decidi se là potranno trovare un pezzo della statuetta draconica.

Um-Durman: Dopo aver trovato i quattro pezzi della statuetta e aver affrontato molte avversità e avventure emozionanti, i personaggi possono finalmente entrare nella cripta sotto il tempio in rovina di Orlo e mettere le mani su @UUID[Item.89Dgq00UCv3MpMou]{Um-Durman}. Questo probabilmente comporterà un confronto con Leanara e i suoi scagnozzi. Se i personaggi avranno successo, ognuno di loro sarà ricompensato con una capacità eroica a loro scelta.

La Leggenda di Um-Durman

È importante che i personaggi sentano la leggenda di Um-Durman all’inizio. Scegli un PNG che racconti loro la storia sottostante: @UUID[Actor.qdhDPr97V8C6RP5F]{Annabella/Leanara} è una buona scelta, ma delle alternative sono @UUID[Actor.qrqvPrdlOZkHORSa]{Alfilia Fogliombrosa}, @UUID[Actor.XerPt1D2yCkugUPr]{Dranath}, @UUID[Actor.dESAouUNSB7OHgi0]{Maladûk} o il ragno matriarca @UUID[Actor.D7u2e7uwVdSG7XUs]{Saak’shal}. La leggenda è anche presente in una carta avventura.

La spada Um-Durman fu forgiata dall’imperatore drago Eledain ottocento anni or sono, quando il mondo era il campo di battaglia di draghi e demoni. È la lama della vita, creata per mantenere l’equilibrio tra ordine e caos.

Per coloro che sono liberi, è un’arma contro gli antichi mali, ma nelle mani sbagliate, Um-Durman diventa un’arma di tirannia, uno strumento di oscurità demoniaca o fuoco draconico.

Dopo la morte di Eledain, la spada fu sepolta in una cripta che può essere aperta soltanto con una chiave speciale: una statuetta divisa in quattro parti, una per ciascuna direzione dove Eledain governava.

La verità è che il luogo oggi conosciuto come Valle Nebbiosa un tempo era il cuore dell’impero di Eledain, e la cripta di Um-Durman è nascosta sotto le rovine del vecchio tempio nel villaggio di Orlo.

Per aprire la cripta, però, servono i quattro pezzi della statuetta. Sono dispersi da secoli, cercati sia dai servitori di Eledain che dai seguaci del principe demoniaco Sathmog. Probabilmente si trovano all’interno di qualche rovina nella Valle Nebbiosa.

L’Isola della Nebbia: Con Um-Durman in loro possesso, i personaggi possono raggiungere l’Isola della Nebbia a nord e affrontare Azrahel Koth. Prima non potevano a causa della nebbia corrosiva che avvolge l’isola, che può essere dispersa solo usando la spada. Sconfiggere lo stregone demoniaco fermerà i piani malvagi di Sathmog, per ora, e farà ottenere a ciascuno dei personaggi un’altra capacità eroica a sua scelta. Ma questo sconvolgerà l’equilibrio tra draghi e demoni?

Demonic Omens.name: Presagi Demoniaci
Demonic Omens.text:
Con l’aumentare del potere di Azrahel Koth e dell’influenza demoniaca di Sathmog, strani e spaventosi presagi iniziano ad apparire nella Valle Nebbiosa. Puoi far sì che i personaggi assistano agli oscuri presagi riportati sotto quando lo ritieni appropriato, che siano a Orlo o lungo la strada. Tira o scegli dalla tabella sottostante. Gli effetti terminano quando Azrahel Koth viene sconfitto.

@DisplayTable[RollTable.dlLzcHqQq9sZ4N4J]{Presagi Demoniaci}

Road's End Inn.name: Road's End Inn
Road's End Inn.text: Rumors speak of the Road’s End Inn a bit east of Outskirt. Several of its guests are said to have vanished without a trace, including a small child, and most recently a shepherd named Antelia. Her family is beside themselves with worry.

The Situation.name: The Situation
The Situation.text:
The person responsible for the disappearances is Stare, an old soothsayer from the Haunted Marshes who was falsely accused of abducting a child. Together with her three dogs, she was locked in a root cellar under an inn by the child’s parents and the innkeeper, who thought Stare would eventually confess. Instead, she died from anger and starvation.

In revenge, Stare has cursed the inn from beyond the veil, trapping its guests and twisting the building into a nightmare version of itself at night. Most of the victims do not realize they are captives.

The player characters could arrive at the Road’s End Inn by chance or because they are searching for the shepherd Antelia (see @UUID[JournalEntry.EobTKNtJU1ScMlAa.JournalEntryPage.z3XTOOWAJdF06jv6]{rumors}). The building, located where the highway ends and the treacherous paths of the Haunted Marshes begin, is shrouded in fog. The simple lanterns by the door glow invitingly through the haze.

Unlike the other adventures in this book, a piece of the dragon emperor’s statuette cannot be found here.

Random Events

For each full stretch the player characters spend in certain places, perhaps searching for something or taking a stretch rest, you can roll D6 on the table below or select a suitable event. The room descriptions indicate where random events can occur.

@DisplayTable[RollTable.yoi3Qdpj3w78RSz3]{Random Events}

@DisplayMonsterDescriptionCard[Actor.uQVXMoP0q8i80BXa named]{Bone Shambler}

Dining Room.name: Dining Room
Dining Room.text:
About twenty guests are chatting, eating, and gambling. Behind the counter stands a high-spirited halfling. The atmosphere and the smell of meat roasting in the fireplace make it impossible not to feel welcome.

  • The Innkeeper: The halfling Helemi runs things from behind the counter with a smile on her face. She is helpful, but dodges questions about missing guests.

  • The food and drink are good and cheap – half the price listed in the Rulebook. Helemi is particularly proud of the house beer and the delicious pork loin. She is happy to offer the player characters a taste.

  • The guests include humans, halflings, and the occa­sional dwarf. Some halflings invite the player charac­ters to a game of @UUID[Item.FTNKXnzhRGcpghb0]{dice}. Most of the guests are cheerful and talkative but respond evasively to questions about missing people. If stats are needed, use @UUID[JournalEntry.NVNCLs3ZE3Xttqk0.JournalEntryPage.SiMaz5ZUTWbfJed8#typical-npcs]{Typical NPCs}.

  • Antelia: One of the guests is Antelia, the missing shepherd. The player characters can learn this by asking Helemi or the guests. She invites the player characters to sit down and brushes aside any questions about her disappearance. “Missing? Oh no, I just walked a bit deeper into the Greatwood than usual.My family worries a lot, that’s all.”

  • Grunn and Edda: Only two of the guests, a young couple, look unhappy. They sit at a table by themselves, drinking in silence. They can reveal their names, but other than that they have no answers to the player characters’ questions.

  • Stig Stonehilt: One of the guests, an impressive-looking dwarf, asks to sit with the player characters. He tells them stories of mining in the Kummer Mountains and of hideous monsters he defeated. Stig is partly aware of the curse, but unable to talk about it. He makes contact with the player characters now in order to talk to them later, at night (see @UUID[.TUTXqWIU0urlW9i6]{Dormitory}).

  • The Curse: The player characters suddenly notice that something is wrong. The walls and ceiling seem to contract inward. Immediately thereafter, everything goes black. Stare’s curse is putting the player characters to sleep – they can do nothing to prevent this, and the same thing happens the moment they try to leave the inn. Then they wake up in the @UUID[.TUTXqWIU0urlW9i6]{Dormitory} at the twisted version of the inn.

Dormitory.name: Dormitory
Dormitory.text:
You wake up in separate beds in an oblong dormitory. It is cold, as if someone opened the window and let the night air in while you slept. Only the moonlight filtering through a large western window illuminates the room. There is a large tapestry hanging on the eastern wall, and to the north is a wooden door. In a black rocking chair in one of the corners sits a person of diminutive stature.

  • Gear: Each player characters’ gear is found at the end of their bed.

  • Tapestry: On the eastern wall hangs a large tapestry of an old woman who seems to be watching the player characters wherever they are in the room. This is Stare.

  • Window: Crooked trees battling gale-force winds can be seen through the western window. A high mountain looms in the distance, with a fire flickering at the summit. A player character who succeeds with a MYTHS & LEGENDS roll realizes that the view is wrong – there are no mountains in that direction. The window cannot be opened or broken, not even by magical means.

  • Rocking Chair: The person in the rocking chair is Stig Stonehilt, fast asleep. He can be woken but is paralyzed and cannot get up. In a tired voice, Stig explains that the player characters, like himself, are trapped in an illusion created by someone he calls “Old Hag Stare.” Stig says she is hiding somewhere in the illusion, and begs the player characters to free him.

  • NORTH: A heavy, creaky oak door. A single torch illuminates a long stone staircase leading down to the @UUID[.CvgmOYBkgbQEIXuq]{storeroom}. The player characters can take the torch with them.

Storeroom.name: Storeroom
Storeroom.text:
The air is stale in this cluttered, windowless room. On a wooden table is a toolbox and on the dusty floor are several chests, most of them forced open. The eastern wall is adorned with a burgundy curtain with shimmering gold patterns.

  • Chests: One of the chests contains valuables equiva­lent to [[/treasure]].

  • Toolbox: The box is locked, and it takes a successful SLEIGHT OF HAND roll to get it open. It is also possible to break the box (25 HP, armor rating 6), but whoever strikes it is hit by a spike that inflicts [[/damage D6 piercing]].

  • Dagger: In the toolbox is a @UUID[Item.fmCy4IhV84UBknpQ]{strange, ornate dagger} whose tip is badly worn. The dagger deals 2D8 damage against Stare but works normally against anyone else.

  • Random Event: Roll on the @UUID[.ovahlBHj5GPG7Ck1#random-events]{Random Events} table for each full stretch the player characters spend here.

  • NORTH: Door to @UUID[.cEB9aPAEBQtyDbNF]{chaotic mosaic}.

  • SOUTH: Long stone staircase to the @UUID[.TUTXqWIU0urlW9i6]{dormitory}.

  • EAST: Behind the curtain is a @UUID[.AzqoGJcUSwDyDz9F]{dirt tunnel}.

Dirt Tunnel.name: Dirt Tunnel
Dirt Tunnel.text:
This dirt tunnel is full of stale darkness, and passing through it feels like being trapped in a coffin. Your footsteps squelch through a rot-black sludge of wet earth. Further ahead, you hear a shuffling sound.

  • Cobwebs: The remains of a giant spider are lying on the ground halfway down the tunnel.Its web is still intact, spun from wall to wall. The player character who goes first must make an AWARENESS roll (with a bane unless the person is carrying a light source) to avoid getting caught in the web, which attracts as many bone sham­blers as there are player characters. Anyone caught in the web is unable to move or perform actions that require body movement. Breaking free requires a successful STR roll with a bane (action). Others can help.

  • Random Event: Roll on the @UUID[.ovahlBHj5GPG7Ck1#random-events]{Random Events} table for each full stretch the player characters spend here.

  • NORTH: Locked door, which can be picked or broken down (10 HP, armor rating 5), leading to the @UUID[.OqwEawIQsjQ9PaeT]{play­room}.

  • NORTHWEST: Side door leading to the @UUID[.cEB9aPAEBQtyDbNF]{chaotic mosaic}.

  • SOUTHWEST: Behind a curtain is the @UUID[.CvgmOYBkgbQEIXuq]{storeroom}.

Chaotic Mosaic.name: Chaotic Mosaic
Chaotic Mosaic.text:
The mosaic on the floor of this room forms a chaotic pat­tern of different colors. The ceiling is several meters high with narrow windows that you cannot reach. From the ceiling hangs a large oil lamp that lights up the room.

  • Three Statues: Along the western wall stand three statues of mourning women. One of them is praying, one is covering her face, and the third is pointing at the floor, toward the floor trap.

  • Trap: In the room there is a hidden trap door with a five-meter drop. A player character actively looking for traps can notice it with a successful SPOT HIDDEN. Among the bones at the bottom of the trap is a golden ring. The ring looks elegant and emits a faint glow – its wearer will have a use for it in the @UUID[.dC5pHGM9i5MRHpHy]{ritual chamber}.

  • Random Event: Roll on the @UUID[.ovahlBHj5GPG7Ck1#random-events]{Random Events} table for each full stretch the player characters spend here.

  • NORTH: Open archway to the @UUID[.CRc665NI37h3nZBl]{underground pond}.

  • SOUTH: Door to the @UUID[.CvgmOYBkgbQEIXuq]{storeroom}.

  • EAST: Door to the @UUID[.AzqoGJcUSwDyDz9F]{dirt tunnel}.

Foundry VTT: Secret Tiles

This room has tiles that hide secrets from the players. Choose Tile Controls and press CTRL+A to mark all tiles on the scene.

Playroom.name: Playroom
Playroom.text:
In the middle of the room is a cradle. Some wooden toys lie scattered on the floor, as if discarded by a child who grew tired of playing with them. There is a painting on the wall. Warmth emanates from the dying embers of a fireplace.

  • The painting depicts a man and a woman with a tod­dler, a small boy, standing in front of a run-down shack with a wild forest behind them. If the players ask if they recognize anyone in the painting, they realize that the man and woman are the unhappy couple in the dining room, if they have met them (Grunn and Edda, see @UUID[.A8PtKrtxmXySJL1Q]{Dining Room}). You can also let them make a passive AWARENESS roll to realize this.

  • Doll: In the cradle lies a porcelain doll that looks a lot like the child in the painting. If the player characters take the doll with them, it comes to life in the @UUID[.dC5pHGM9i5MRHpHy]{ritual chamber}. Underneath the doll is a bone flute (tiny item). The flute starts playing melancholic tunes when­ever the bearer comes within 10 meters of an undead creature.

  • Random Event: Roll on the @UUID[.ovahlBHj5GPG7Ck1#random-events]{Random Events} table for each full stretch the player characters spend here.

  • SOUTH: Door with a key in its lock, leading to the @UUID[.AzqoGJcUSwDyDz9F]{underground tunnel}.

  • WEST: Door to the @UUID[.CRc665NI37h3nZBl]{underground pond}.

Underground Pond.name: Underground Pond
Underground Pond.text:
Beautiful trickling sounds are heard from a pond. The drops hitting the surface of the water sound like a sad creature playing the harp. One detail disturbs the har­mony – the occasional croak echoing off the walls.

  • Pond: Water flowing from a hole in the wall creates a small waterfall down to a pond filled with lily pads. There are several large frogs as well.

  • Box: Player characters examining the pond notice a sealed box about four meters beneath the surface. The box contains valuables equivalent to [[/treasure 2]].

  • Frogs: The frogs are completely harmless, but stubbornly get in the way if anyone wades out into the water. It takes a successful EVADE roll not to become Angry.

  • Random Event: Roll on the @UUID[.ovahlBHj5GPG7Ck1#random-events]{Random Events} table for each full stretch the player characters spend here.

  • NORTH: Creaky door to the @UUID[.mthBezxG2ZljKZ5v]{gallery}.

  • SOUTH: Open archway to the @UUID[.cEB9aPAEBQtyDbNF]{chaotic mosaic}.

  • EAST: Door to the @UUID[.OqwEawIQsjQ9PaeT]{playroom}.

Gallery.name: Gallery
Gallery.text:
This large hall exudes tranquility. It is empty save for the eight paintings hanging on the walls. Moonlight streams down through a dome in the ceiling.

  • Glass Dome: A cloudless night sky can be seen through the glass dome in the ceiling, bathing the whole gallery in moonlight and starlight.

  • Paintings: The paintings are sparsely painted in ocher, green, dark red, and black. They depict temples from the time of the Dragon Empire, which the player characters can realize with a MYTHS & LEGENDS roll. Each painting counts as a normal item and is worth 50 silver coins. A player character who examines the paintings and succeeds with a SPOT HIDDEN roll notices that one of the paintings in the background shows a family using a large outdoor oven to bake bread. These are the same people depicted in the paint­ing in the @UUID[.OqwEawIQsjQ9PaeT]{playroom}.

  • Gas Trap: If four or more paintings are removed, lethal gas (Potency 9) spews out from tiny holes in the floor.

  • Reflection: A sense of peace washes over the player characters if they choose to simply enjoy the art. The player characters can take an extra stretch rest here, in addition to the one they normally get each shift.

  • NORTH: Short stone staircase leading up to a black­ened portal and the @UUID[.dC5pHGM9i5MRHpHy]{ritual chamber}. A player character who has passed through the portal cannot return the same way.

  • SOUTH: Creaking door to the @UUID[.CRc665NI37h3nZBl]{underground pond}.

Ritual Chamber.name: Ritual Chamber
Ritual Chamber.text:
A chain rattles in the darkness. You see a pair of glowing eyes and the sickly gleam of decaying teeth. A pulsing smell of sulfur assaults your nostrils as the figure approaches and finally attacks with a chilling shriek.

  • Darkness: The chamber is pitch black, and no fire can live in Stare’s presence. Torches and lanterns go out. See the rules for @UUID[JournalEntry.SbbSMsuvWeo3HaID.JournalEntryPage.6WPxPxUjh4W80RNy#darkness]{darkness} in the Rulebook – before each attack, a player character must succeed with an AWARENESS roll (not action).

  • The Ring: Stare immediately attacks the player charac­ters. However, she will not target a person wearing the ring from @UUID[.cEB9aPAEBQtyDbNF]{Chaotic Mosaic}.

  • The Doll: If the player characters brought the doll from the @UUID[.OqwEawIQsjQ9PaeT]{playroom}, it slowly begins to move. It says nothing but keeps looking at the hag. The doll does not deal any damage, but the sight of it makes Stare excited and increases her Ferocity by one. Destroying the doll counts as an action.
